jim's trucking

This thread is prompted by Kronus' offer to explain the whole thing to me. I think radical Muslims want to convert or kill us all. Kronus will explain why I am wrong...he thinks.
 
 Others are welcome to post.

post_info.post_title: What is it that the radical Muslims want?

Kronus

Well, let's start with what you actually said, that which I actually disagreed with:
 
 "There's also Sharia Law...convert of I will behead you...we won't wait for God to send you to hell when you die...we'll kill you ourselves if you don't comply."
 
 There's lots wrong in there. First off, Sharia law. It simply does not say "convert or die". It's Muslim law. It applies only to Muslims, or in a few instances those who are dealing directly with Muslims. There's nothing in there about conversion on pain of death.
 
 Is "convert or die" a Islamic creedo? Absolutely not. The Koran is quite clear on how to treat non-believers.
 "Fight for the sake of God those the fight against you, but do not attack them first. God does not love the aggressors." I've read most of the Koran, and I've not seen word one that would support any sort of "convert or die" concept.
 
 Now, if you want to shift the goal posts to only cover radical Muslims, you're still off base. Sure, someone who fits your discription probably exists; there are 6 billion people in the world after all. But what does your average Islamic terrorist want, what are they fighting for? Two things. U.S. out of the middle east, and the U.S. to stop supporting Isreal. That's it, nothing about convert or die. If conversion were truly their goal, why target the most powerful and least accesible nation? That would be stupid on more levels than I could count. No, the terrorist's goals are political, not religious. I've come across some conservative fearmongers who would like people to think otherwise, but I've never seen any actual facts that support that assertion.
Kronus

So, since Jim has not yet decided to respond, I'll ask my own question. What do conservatives want?
 
 While doing some reading on this subject I googled "islam" "convert or die". The results were mostly references to the conservative blogosphere. Apparently conservatives really want people to accept as fact the disinformation that Islam has a "convert or die" agenda. This seems odd. I would have thought islamic terrorists crashing planes into the world trade center would have been enough of a rallying cry for those who had it in for islam. Why invent a bogus rationale? I can't say for sure, of course, but I'll toss out some guesses.
 
 If your opponent has a political agenda, then a solution is possible. Even if their demands are ludicrous, even if you won't talk with them, those forming policy will not always be in charge. Either through old age or more violent means someone else will be forming policy eventually, and they might be more reasonable. Thus, an end is potentially in sight. If your foe has a religious agenda, on the other hand, than no peaceful resolution is possible. If their goal actually was "convert or die", and this was an actuall religious duty, then a peacful resolution is pretty much out of the question. Thus, the only solution is a "final" solution. If peaceful coexistence is out of the question, then utterly destroying your enemy is your only option.
 
 If genocide isn't what the conservatives are hinting at, then what? I don't know enough about the conservative mind set to know if this is close to the mark or not, but could it be about Isreal? The bulk of the trouble we have with Islamic radicals springs from our support of Isreal. On the one hand, we're stuck supporting Isreal at this point, there's no way that will change any time soon. On the other hand, Isreal is a jewish state, how happy can the religious right be that we're risking so much for them? So if you wanted to win over the R.R. an obivous ploy would be to make it seem like Islam had it in for everyone, even the Christians. If you shift the point of the terrorism from politics to religion then you can guarantee the continued support of the religious right. I'm not pushing this as necessarily true, just tossing it out as something to think about.
 
 Any other ideas? Should this get moved to politics?
Zardoz

Well, it depends on which strawman you're stomping on.
 
 Jim's is so because it extrapolates on what has been pushed forward by some terrorists.
 Reading a call to 'convert or suffer the consequences' (which IIRC were made by the American convert to Islam and here is the 1st link that popped up in my google search ) into comments that have been made. Or interpreting that infidels must die for (xxx) reason into comments that have also been made isn't hard to do.
 
 I mean, an American convert and member of Al Qaeda who states the comments in this particular video...you know, Al Qaeda "we brought your 9/11 without warning...stating 'today may be your last day' doesn't really sound like the crocodile tear laded messages by some Christians to 'convert...or face eternal hellfire.'
 
 So, I think Jim could be forgiven for jumping to some obvious conclusions.
 I mean, seriously, I've hit people in the faces with Louisville sluggers for less threatening 'threats' by them and I've been arrested myself for less intimidating forms of 'terrorism'.
 
 And, yeah, I think Jim's call of extermination, to more sane ears, would sound a bit knee jerkish and extreme.
 But, this isn't a rose colored world we live in. And while you want to negotiate with obviously insane, bloodthirsty mad men who's 1st reaction to a problem is to blow something up, I really don't think that will work. Seems to me it hasn't in past attempts.
 I find it quaint that you think talking will miraculously solve problems (that really don't exist except to a fringe group).
 
 
 I don't know.
 Jim did state he thought this is what the radicals want and asked for some rebuttal.
 
 Your rebuttal is to state the comments come from conservative blogs...opps sorry, you said 'MOSTLY' come from them. 
 Mostly implies not all. 
 Mostly is also a (IMO) subjective term.
 And seeing as how most of the Internet sources one would visit in a GOOGLE search in English would bring you to something based in the Western world (and probably not sympathetic to the terrorists due to the 'war on terror' thingy and chance of being raided by the police if it's tracked back to you) I doubt your search (or most of anyone else's 15 sec. search would dig up much from an actual terrorists site to get a real understanding.
 So, your average Joe is left to go by what the terrorists via western media sources like the neo-fascist CNN, MSNBC, NBC, CBS, ABC, CNBC, Reuters or any number of neo-Con sources like WGN and Fox or the BBC push forward.
 
 Stooopid fascist BBC news.
 "Separately, Palestinian militants who held two Fox News journalists hostage for almost two weeks last month vowed to target all non-Muslims who entered the Palestinian territories. 
 
 "Any infidel blood will have no sanctity," the Holy Jihad Brigades group said in a statement posted on the Internet. 
 
 The group, which was previously unknown, had forced the captured journalists to convert to Islam at gunpoint, according to one of the released hostages."
 
 
 Yeah, yeah. They have nothing on the crusaders from hundreds of years ago (my own strawman for today's post). I'm fondly reminded of one Crusader who had an entire city of 100,000 converts from Islam to Christianity put to the sword...so they would die Christian deaths and not have a chance to back slide.
 But, if religions have a trend to exclaim, from time to time, 'convert or die', made by their radical zealots, it's not hard to look at Islam's 'Jihad' and think that this century, the pendulum is on the other side with similar comments being made towards us.
 
 
 Oh well.
 That's my somewhat disjointed .02
 I've always lived by the ethos of ''Oderint dum metuant'' or, 'let them hate...so long as they fear.'
 But, if you want, you can interpret that to actually mean 'Why can't we all jus' git along?'
jyoshu

I'm not sure going by the letter of the law of the Koran is necessarily the best way to show what Muslims want or don't want. I think it shows what the Koran says they should do, but that's not necessarily the same thing. It's the same idea as holding up the teachings of Jesus to 'turn the other cheek' and 'love your enemies' and say that such texts demonstrate what Christians want--yet Christians don't seem to do that all too often. The same likely applies with the Koran and Muslims; it's a religious morals-type book at the center of a mainline religion, so I cna't think of any reason it wouldn't also play out like that.
 
 Also, I'm also not sure I'd agree that the goals of radical Muslims are limited to getting the US out of the ME and for the US to stop supporting Israel. There have been too many "we-want-Israel-annihalated"-type statements to assume their goals are that benign.
 
 If conservative sources aren't good enough, then by all means check out non-conservative sources on this. I did the same Google search and by merely clicking on more than one page was able to find NON-"conservative" source reporting of such cases as Muslim convert-or-die cases. (http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6412453.stm )
 
 But like so many threads of this nature, this is largely about generalization. It's highly unlikely that there aren't some Muslims who don't have a convert-or-die mentality. But I know for a fact many of them don't; I've been around some that are very peaceful and willing to co-exist with Christians. Bottom line: it depends on the Muslim and his individual beliefs.

 It looks like 4-56 has to do with somebody besides God. It says "we shall roast them" it doesn't say God shall roast them. 

 If you knew anything about the Koran you would know that was, in essence, the "royal We". The Koran, it is said, was dictated by God, and he often refers to himself in the plural, just like British royalty.
 
 

 8-60
 prepare for them whatever force and cavalry ye are capable of gathering...to strike terror...to strike terror into the hearts of the enemies, of Allah and your enemies. 

 This isn't 8:60. I don't know where you got it from, but it isn't 8:60. And, just to add insult to injury, it also utterly fails to support your "convert or die" claims.
 
 

 4-56
 Those who have disbelieved our signs, we shall roast them in fire whenever their skins are cooked to a turn, we shall substitute new skins for them that they may feel the punishment: verily Allah is sublime and wise.

 47-4
 Therefore when ye meet the unbelievers, smite at their necks and when you have caused a bloodbath among them bind a bond firmly on them. 

 Deliberate mistranslation, I suspect. Real translation, with bits left out that show you to be wrong emphasized:
 "When you meet the unbelievers on the battlefield strike off their heads and, when you have laid them low, bind your captives firmly. Then grant them their freedom or take a ransom from them, until war shall lay down her burdens
 
 

 4-89
 They but wish that ye should reject faith as they do, and thus be on the same footing as they, so take not friends from their ranks until they flee in the way of Allah. 

 This says don't befriend unbelievers, lest they drag you into their disbelief. Not exactly "convert or die" now, is it?
 
 

 It appears there is some discrepancy between what you read and what I read.

 Here, I'll print the crucial parts for you.
 

 Bin Laden and other Islamic radicals claim they represent ancient Islam. It is true that they do represent one tradition in Islam, but it is a tradition that Islam early on rejected as opposed to the universal message of its Prophet. In the earliest centuries of Islam, a great civil war was fought over who should be the successor to Muhammad. The battle was between the partisans of the assassinated third Caliph, Uthmann, and those who supported the fourth Caliph, 'Ali. This was the conflict that ultimately led to the division between Sunni and Shi'a Islam. But there was a moment when a truce and an arbitration promised a possible peaceful resolution to the conflict. 
 
 One group was adamantly opposed to any arbitration and any compromise. Later called the Kharajites, this sect believed that only God could determine who should be the proper successor, and God would let his will be known in battle. The Kharajites withdrew and made war on both factions. They held that any person who strayed from the perfect practice of Islam was ipso facto an apostate and could be killed. And they believed that only they had the true notion of what Islam required. They applied their doctrine with a ferocity against both the developing Sunni and Shi'a traditions of Islam, even assassinating 'Ali. Their tactics were frightfully violent, and it took centuries before they were put down. 
 
 Today, radicals like bin Laden replicate that ancient sect that threatened to destroy Islamic civilization at its inception. They copy that sect that stood against what came to be a civilization known in its time for its learning, science, openness and toleration. They engage in tactics that are far beyond what is acceptable in the Islamic moral tradition. They insult the vast multitudes of Muslims who abhor such actions.
